block.para: A subvector space of \RNr[n] is a collection of vectors V containing the 0-vector and which is closed under vector addition and scalar multiplication of a vector in V by a number. Here is a visual interpretation of what this means.

li.para: If \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} are vectors in V, then \Vect{x}+\Vect{y} is also in V.
If \Vect{x} is a vector in V, and t is a number, then t \Vect{x} is also in V.

figure.caption: The sum of two vectors in V is again in V.
The scalar multiple of \Vect{x} by any number is again in V.

block.para: In contrast, here is a subset V of \RNr[2] which is not a subvector space.

Indeed, there are (at least) two vectors \Vect{x} and \Vect{y} in \RNr[3] whose sum \Vect{x} + \Vect{y} is not in V; i.e. this line is not closed under vector addition, hence is not a subvector space.
